messages: 820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (11:52): i was wanting to end recording the macro while in insert mode, normally you'd have to hit <Esc> and type q to end it
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (11:53): but.. if you type Ctrl-o q in insert mode, that'll do it.
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:01): running the macro from insert mode (via ctrl+o @register) works too...
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:03): i dont find macros useful though
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:03): oh they are so useful for me
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:03): well.. i suppose they were more useful before i knew of bufdo and windo
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:04): what do you do with them?
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:05): i just used a macro to auto find the next input element, go to the end of it, insert name="" and end in insert mode with the cursor between the ""
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:05): i wish vim had code snippets
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:06): i dont know what they are..
09dd385295bbbceb3983f0de471e6ef0 (12:07): does vim have a  place to report bugs?
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:17): wtf are code snippets? you mean something like :r!~/.vim/snippets/snippetname
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:17): phrakture: like that, but more flexible. check the ruby on rails video
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:18): that seems to be what made it famous
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:18): you mean snippets with like "replace me" type functionality ?
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:18): i like number 6 on that list..
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:19): tpope: there's stuff that can do that already
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:20): imaps is the closest I've seen but it's still kind of ugly
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:20): still, it can be done with vimscript
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:21): and it can't do that whole "copy what I write in the first part to the third part" thing
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:21): yes but there's no elegant drop in replacement.  hopefully with the new programming features and autocommands we'll see some cool stuff pop up
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:22): course.. we'll have to wait for vim7 to be available for all machines..
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:23): hardly. people can start writing the scripts now
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:23): as i'm not the admin of the box i primarily use it.
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:23): yeah and I don't want to screw up my debian stable boxes
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:23): that's what my bro is doing (he's the admin)
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:24): i think i'm still usin vim6.3
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:25): still i want what textmate does
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:25): or become a vim sponser and vote for it
b37d36abbe15c01bab5692ac99ac40fb (12:27): how can I enable help window when I press ctrl+n  ?
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:27): did it make it to unstable yet?
b37d36abbe15c01bab5692ac99ac40fb (12:27): sanmarcos: yes in experimental I got sources from experimental and recompiled under ubuntu breezy
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:27): dunno it will make it soon
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:28): he used the debian experimental sources though
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:29): ubuntu and debian packages shouldnt mix
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:29): i dont use ubuntu because they dont have an unstable branch
7b5c67f5c3939fdd882f457f722a8d08 (12:29): besides, its community is full of newbies
b37d36abbe15c01bab5692ac99ac40fb (12:30): yes ubuntu community don't help me much
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:30): visik7: help when you press C-n ? a) what's wrong with :help, b) you're overwriting the normal C-n operation
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:31): as to your original question visik7.. a mapping would work...

b37d36abbe15c01bab5692ac99ac40fb (12:31): on a vim7 installation in a friend of mine's pc there is a window on the top when it press ctrl+n for each possible completation vim describe what the method do
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:32): make sure "filetype plugin indent on" is in your vimrc
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:32): err for ^N you don't even need that
0792377b948579515cfdf726e83cbc23 (12:33): ^N by itself completes words from your buffers
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:33): is that a vim7 only thing?
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:34): your answer is in :help completeopt
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (12:37): the great phrakture has spoken
820eaff364b5f2f1ce787f9a5f4ac39a (12:37): lot of sarcasm and such tonight
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:38): no, he was asking about the preview window for omni completion - not about omni-completion or vim7
b37d36abbe15c01bab5692ac99ac40fb (12:44): seems not be enough (or I misunderstood the meaning of this settings)
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:46): window is not a completeopt setting
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:46): configuration based on guessing never works
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (12:46): ok, then hit "C-x,C-o" - the preview info depends on the omni function in place
